security and in AWS we've integrated it into all of our services for example if
you're using red shift our data warehouse service it encrypts all data by
default with have a random key for each data block and then take that set of random keys and enps it with a master
key you can bring the master key we can generate it for you but that way you are the only one who decides who has access
to the data that you process in your data warehouse important in all of this is
not just to use the tools but to think about from day one when you start building things to integrate security
into that by Design security is not something you can sprinkle over it afterwards is not a

don't do that we protect individual building blocks and as such you need to
do this by Design Amazon of AWS really urges our
customers to take a look at security by Design basically four different phases phase one is where you look at your

management there what are the things that are unique for your customer base and what are the sort of controls

environment making use of access management Network segmentations resource constraints all the tools that
we give you to implement those requirements and then make use of templates to
enforce the use of templates to make sure that only those preapproved secure environments
can be launched you can use service catalog for that and then of course you do the validation you can use config
rules for that or against inspector so security by Design is incredibly
important tool for you to think about how to build secure systems AWS we have a whole website

thank you wow what a great audience and thank you for having me here today to speak to you this is great my name is
Ian mccormac and I'm one of the technical directors from the UK's National cyber security Center I'm

user needs that the service exists to deliver against so I observe that one of the
issues we need to deal with is that we focused our security analysis through the lens of compliance with our own

things that we genuinely and actually care about using ambiguous policies on our
own unique terminology within the UK government resulted in bespoke or if you
like designed specifically just for us Solutions and that came with some issues it came with significant complexity very

we got less security over time because the technology would Age now I'm certainly not saying that
compliance with policy has no place but it does start to become an issue when the focus is on compliance rather than
actually delivering against the needs that we have and maintaining actual contextualized
security so if we're going to support the uh the ambition to change how we work the digital services that we
deliver and the technology we use we need to make a paradigm shift in how we approach security and I think one of the most
significant things we did was we totally overhauled our old Legacy classification
system it dated all the way back to the second world war and we replaced it with a much
simpler much easy to understand three- tier system and the L of those Street tiers was a level that we call official
and it's really interesting because it covers the vast majority of government needs it covers data supporting needs
that represent the most basic and routine of administration right up to needs other are towards that National
Security boundary and because we had such a massive diversity of need and official it means that it's just not
possible to take a one-sized fits-all approach to either technology or security it requires active decision-
making by service owners with knowledge of what needs protecting and why it needs
protecting now as one of the Geeks in the National cyber security Center we've actually gone on quite a transformative
Journey ourselves we genuinely get that government is here to serve the public
and its purpose isn't to implement our arbitrary security rules and so we developed a new mantra and this was
quite counterintuitive for us we developed this Mantra that says user experience should be
fantastic security should be good enough and that's quite culturally
challenging for us professional but I really like the statement I really love it and why I like it is because it absolutely underlines our commitment to
helping colleagues like Tom who's going to come up on the stage shortly deliver excellent services with the security
that he needs as the senior official responsible for that service okay so I've discussed our
security philosophy a little and now I'd like to illustrate this with our approach to Cloud I think it's pretty reasonable and
fair to say that there Still Remains a fair amount of mystery and dare I say Prejudice towards cloud and
security we need to remove some of that fog if we're going to help decision makers make active and good decisions we
need to give people the tools to reason about their security meaningfully and we need to help them describe the security
requirements in a consistent way that can be
understood we did this through an approach we described as our Cloud security principles there are 14 of them
it's really important to say these are not standards these are not requirements it is not
possible to be compliant with the cloud security principles what they are is 14 areas
where a security decision needs to be made plus we provide a whole range of information and guidance about the
implications of the various decisions that it's possible to make as well and the best bit about them they're written
in plain English they're very easy to understand at the high level and our aim here is to help as I've alluded to help
to makers make informed decisions and so with this Clarity of understanding plus our needs described
in a consistent way it starts to become possible to compare the security needs that we hold with the attributes of the
services that are available in the marketplace now a number of vendors
including Amazon web service Services publish a lot of guidance lot of
information that describe the security attributes of the services they provide map back to our principles and this is
great this is great because it's really helpful for our customers in the UK to understand how these Services can meet
their needs that they've defined us in our framework and similarly whilst we do not mandate the
use of any particular compliance certification many of the services hold
certificates and it can actually be useful as a tool to demonstrate confidence that the security attributes
that you care about are well implemented and are accurately portrayed
now finally it Still Remains the case that there is a number of myths regarding cloud service security and
these myths represent still a significant barrier to adoption and it's something we're trying really really hard to bust actually we we spoke about
some of these in a bit more detail earlier on today in the security track so I'm just going to touch on three of the really significant ones as we see
them right now firstly it's often said to us that due to the global nature of a
service it's somehow inherently less secure than if exactly the same service was hosted in a data center in the UK
but actually that just doesn't stand up to technical scrutiny outside of particular National Security type
applications people often say to us yeah but you can't know who's got access to your
data and that's a legitimate question to ask but actually it's one that service providers take incredibly
seriously most service providers provide an extraordinary amount of detail and information that describe how they
manage that particular issue is usually the case that very very few individuals have got the facilities
and the ability to access data and that if they do it's very very heavily audited and of course you should be
using encryption Services anyway finally I think it's legitimate to look
at how infrastructure is maintained patched and operated after at least 10 years of
giving advice to many public sector organizations in the UK to patch we've reached the conclusion that we're not
actually very good at it so if we can rely on a competent
Cloud hosting provider to do some of that for us and to do it well and we don't need to worry about it we believe

together we've moved from approach an approach of compliance-based security
